pros: fun, healthy environment, good management
cons: parking is a pain, so you have to use public transit

review_title: Benefits are the only good thing
pros: The benefits are really good and that's the only reason I stayed as long as I did.
cons: OHSU is a bubble. So many employees have only worked there, or have worked there for so long that it's all they know, and because of this are very resistant to change and updating practices, especially within HR. Systems and practices used at OHSU are very out of date and there are very limited up-to-date written procedures. The new CPO is initiating change that is much needed, but so many managers are resistant and are giving so much pushback to this change because it goes against their outdated practices. Aside from the overall change needed, I personally had an awful experience within the mission that I worked in. I was there for months and never received any formal training on procedures or any tasks that I would be taking on. I was constantly disregarded by my manager after asking for more training and asking for feedback about how I can be successful. I had to navigate so much of my job on my own and just hope for the best. Time and time again I also was shown that faculty is above all and get what they want. This was easily one of the worst jobs I've ever had and was so disappointing. I was so excited to work for a large renowned organization and was very let down.

job_title: Senior Contract Manager in Portland, OR
pros: Great flexibility, able to ask questions and implement improvements; organization open to positive change. Doing important work developing and delivering life saving health care innovations every day. Great leadership. Autonomy in our work. Supportive culture.
cons: Not always super competitive which can lead to some complacency. Everyone works hard here so it's only a vague awareness that because we have so much support and understanding, there is the opportunity to abuse it. (We don't.) Pay is also not competitive though and that's a hard pill to swallow. Every day I am grateful, even with a paycut, for the improvement in my qualify of life working here vs other local health systems and health plans. OHSU has a collaborative, curious culture that promotes transparency. I think much of that comes from being a part of an academic medical center that leads research.... it bleeds into all areas of the organization, which is a great thing. It feels good to be providing services that are not available other places and to be developing new things. Some of the challenges with new, like everywhere, is that it requires some pivots.... we don't always get it right the first time, which is okay because again - the organization supports change and makes it okay to make mistakes in the name of learning.

review_title: Well resourced hospital that actually uses its resources for pt. care
job_title: Operating Room Nurse in Portland, OR
pros: I didn't realize how much I took for granted until after I left this place. This is a high-accountability organization with the highest standard of care for patients. The interprofessional culture was very positive and collaborative. OHSU really invests in their employees so that we can provide the best care for the community. The unit I worked in was well-resourced with plenty of support staff. There were clear expectations according to specific roles and nearly universal adherence to policies. My managers were very supportive of me when I had to go on bereavement and basically told me to take as much time as I needed when I was technically only owed 2 weeks per union contract. The staff lounge is pretty great too with a beautiful view of the city, river and mountain. Vacation time + sick time is way better than PTO.
cons: Parking sucks - you can pay ~$11/day to park on the hill (less for a further away parking spot) or you can take public transportation which isn't that bad and might include a tram ride.

review_title: If you're BIPOC, this one is for you.
pros: I'll be honest, I had to think about something that was a "pro" but without sounding spiteful, there was nothing that really came to mind. Prior to transferring to outpatient pharmacy, I was working in a different department within OHSU. It was a temporary position during the pandemic, it was WFH, excellent/supportive supervisors/managers, and really rad co-workers. That's that only reason I'll give it two stars, frankly, if I didn't have to account for outpatient pharmacy during my time at OHSU.
cons: I'm sure you're reading this and hoping for at least one person to bring it into conversation. The overt prejudicial/racist behaviour was clear as day, but only because I was able to recognize it as it happened. I won't get into semantics, but if you have any friends/family that have mentioned it: pay attention to them. Take it seriously. Or, just at a bare minimum: just glance at the Covington Report, and then read their statement as a response. Don't even had to read the entire report-- just take a few pages.

job_title: Registered Nurse, Oncology in Portland, OR

review_title: Will miss my coworkers but not the corporation
pros: On a departmental level, there are many amazing and patient people to work with.
cons: Despite OHSU touting their commitment to medical research they do not value their research staff. Research workers are valued less than clinic staff. There are no longterm protections for research workers. OHSU views research workers as dispensable and views the positions as transitional even though some positions, like my own, require doctorate degrees. On top of all this, OHSU pays their research staff less equitably than the national average. I loved the people I worked with on a departmental level but OHSU does not foster the conditions for a sustainable longterm research career. I would never be able to get any meaningful raise and there is no opportunity for advancement so I decided to leave. Overnight, I will make $15,000 more per year. Leaving OHSU was a no-brainer.

review_title: Get out. Been here a decade and it just keeps getting worse.
job_title: Clinical Research Associate in Portland, OR
pros: There's good health insurance. It is also a huge organization so there are a handful of supervisors and managers who are good to work for, but they are in the minority and are limited by HR are upper management.
cons: This is the most heartless, soul sucking employer you can imagine. Aggressively anti-union. HR and department level administration exist solely to save face and save money. Pay is abysmal compared to similar employers. They completely restructured their research classifications in 2022 after realizing the titles were so bogus that it was literally impossible for them to adhere to pay equity laws. During that process, they held a town hall to answer questions about the new systems and paygrades. One person asked how cost of living was accounted for in the paygrades and, I kid you not, HR said "Cost of living is not a factor in determining paygrades, only cost of labor." Well, unfortunately the whole thing was a sham anyway because even with the new more specific classifications, they are still twisting things to keep people boxed into lower paying classifications even when they don't fit your job description. Real equitable. Being such a large institution, there are many, many, many smaller groups and each one has their own manager and supervisors. If you get lucky enough to have bosses who actually want to fight for you (promotions, market rate pay, etc.), they will often be denied by HR. If you are unlucky and have a boss who fosters an unsafe and/or unethical work environment (12+ hour days with no protected breaks, salaried but not allowed to flex your unpaid overtime, having PTO denied for no legitimate reason, etc.) then HR will protect them and basically tell you tough luck.

review_title: Pay is not as competitive as industry but job security is better

cons:
-Compensate not as good as industry (to be expected).
-If you want a decent raise and promotion, you have to look for a new job.
-Merit based increases are half of the inflation rate, if there is any raise.
-Pay to park you car at work.
-Part hospital system so in financial turmoil.
-In research labs, your training and career mobility lies in the hands of your PI, who is not trained in management or people skills. Sometimes your PI is great, sometimes they are not.
-Clinical workers are unionized but researchers are not.

They allow me to be a mom first before an employee and respect and actually value and appreciate that I have a kid. Never once have I felt like I needed to choose work over life or family stuff.
cons: Can be boring for some, there are slow times of the year and really really busy times of the year but it balances out in my opinion. Those who need direct supervision and management are not going to like this role. My boss always emphasizes that she does not like micro managing, so if you're not able to thrive independently most times, it's not going to be good for you. She does however provide support and answers and helps with any questions or help I need. My department is great, but because its such a huge organization that employs a ton of people...experiences vary from department to department. I know others who are burnt out and worked to the max. Also, automation is taking over many aspects of my job but because OHSU isn't all the way there yet, I see my job being around for a while longer. 5-10 years from now it may not exist in the same capacity.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Portland, OR
pros:
-getting to meet the patients, very interesting stories
-helping the patients through a difficult period in their lives, explaining their rights
-most of the nurses and staff were welcoming to me as a new staff
-top pay and benefits for psych in Portland, just unionized 
-decent training period, I think for me I had about 12 shifts with a partner
-med scanning system works well
-locked parking lot
-the shift supervisors I encountered were some of the most amazing nurses I’ve watched. Several of the nurses on the floor are very talented too.
cons:
-lots of pointless CYA charting and online trainings
-many of the staff just did not seem kind to the patients. The people who were celebrated picked up a ton of shifts so most (with one significant exception in my mind) of them were overworked and cranky. I saw nurses snap at patients multiple times. Staff talked smack about and made fun of patients in the break room. Routinely called security just to intimidate patients over minor rule violations-not trauma informed at all! I would have hoped that Black Lives Matter would inspire Unity to be less “cop-y” but no luck. “Show of force” bs. The security staff are pretty cool and they wear street clothes but patients are very reactive to them because they do still give off law enforcement vibes and many if not most of the patients have trauma from police. 
-constant, constant power struggles with patients over many rules; this might be normal in psych but I’m trying to create a review that would be useful for nurses from other fields considering working here.
-just not a great place for patients to stay which is depressing to work in because you have so little to offer them in the way of comfort or therapy-no quality recreation in a harsh and rigid rule based environment. 
-too much floating they put me on the high acuity floor against my protests after only being there five months. They float without rhyme or reason; you should be with the same patients as much as possible. If you’re trying to be patient centered, as they claimed incessantly.
-some of the nurses they brought in to cover shifts were not well trained or oriented at all.
-the staff just complained constantly even though they had the best working conditions I’ve ever been in. I’m not saying don’t advance workers rights, always push for the workers’ conditions to improve!- but the negativity of the staff was not warranted. Nursing in general sucks and sucks even more during the pandemic but at least on my unit it was a culture of bonding through complaining.
-scheduling is confusing and all over the place. Different week to week, it’s nice because you can sort of pick your shifts (I’d say preferences in my case were respected 90% of the time) but you do this well in advance, up to 2 months and at least no one in my life, including me plans that far ahead. Also even as a millennial, I found the software used unintuitive and the process stressful.

job_title: Patient Access Specialist in Portland, OR
pros: High income, great benefits, (mostly) happy employees
cons: More flexibility for telecommuting. There’s a lot of barriers in place for PAS staff to work from home in my department. Our leadership placed all other admin employees on telecommuting but required all PAS staff to stay in clinic. I was able to get telecommuting status after I involved the union due to my health condition. In order to do that, I had to agree to relinquish all of my duties and go on full time phone support instead, whereas my previous duties that I had been working for over a year, did not involve incoming phone support. I am barred from assisting in my previous workload while they train my replacement and my coworkers ended up having to pull more into their scope because of it. Could’ve been prevented if leadership had just let me work from home in my same capacity, which I proved capable when we went into modified operations in March - June when I worked from home without any issues. This action reads as retaliatory in response to me advocating for myself and my personal health and has created a rift between myself and my leadership. Glad I can work remotely and avoid the in office drama, however my friends and coworkers are not as lucky.

review_title: Ok benefits, ok pay, ok management.
pros: Wage for administrative support positions is better than most places in town. Benefits are good. Union representation ensures a greater degree of job stability.
cons:
Location: OHSU takes a while to get to on public transit; parking on campus is extremely limited (several year wait list) and what parking they have is very expensive if you work in support ($125/month is usual).
The wage is better than most places in town, but it is still below the median for the nation, whereas the cost of living is several percentage points higher. For clerical positions represented by the union, OHSu pays most of the cost of insurance premiums for the employee. They will on pay part of the cost for a spouse and, if you work part-time, they pro-rate the cost of the benefits so you will pay more while earning less. Also, the union (AFSCME) seems to do little in the way of actually improving conditions for employees. If you run into trouble and want their help, you have to pay an additional fee to be a 'fair share member.' Otherwise, they won't return your calls.
OHSU lays off staff regularly 'in anticipation' of budget shortfalls. I've been laid of twice since I started there.
In general, leadership does not want a clerical union. Physicians and researchers do not want to hire sufficient staff to complete the workload in their functional areas. Also, it should be noted that the physicians and researchers at OHSU are generally extremely egoistic and not terribly kind to those who are not their peers. This is accepted as 'usual' at the institution.

review_title: UNSATISFACTORY Heavy work loads which include POOR leadership by some Management
job_title: Property Specialist I in Portland, OR
pros: Being able to work with good individuals that become close to you as friends. No need for gym time outside of work (able to lose weight while getting paid; with right diet and workload). Quiet when less employers during the day depending on hours scheduled (e.g nightshift). Parking space available at hours where most employers are finished with work.
cons: Poor management by supervisor, no supervisor until a large portion of your specific job duty and title of it is complete. When work is all done, additional work consists of irrelevant tasks ensues. (E.g. when all your required duties are complete, more random physically demanding backbreaking tasks continue). Management takes advantage of our health and mental health by working us to the bone. On some occasions management will not greet or look at you for a millisecond. The only acknowledgment you will receive is a 10pm phone call by management with the purpose of getting you to work another brutal 8 hours for a person that is also suffering like you. Keep in mind this will be on your day off to recover from the stress and physical toll on your body. Living farther away from work increases gas mileage, thus gas consumption for motor vehicle skyrockets. Getting paid the bear minimum is hard to keep up with living expenses, car payments, basic life bills to be alive. Management especially promises one thing to you and you even see it on paper, but some how along the line you can tell that you are being lied, spat at and coerced to the point of having no hope by what they say anymore. (E.g. offered a new job position or promotion, it is never guaranteed even when upper high management tells you and you agree and accept the new offer). Lack of females working, male dominated field doing physical work). Becomes awkward to socialize with females or remember how to talk when only with males. High turnover rate with employers. Job openings are unsecured, many temp jobs with high termination rate, no job security even when FTE. Employers need to do work that is unsafe, no body covered suits when handling patient wastes that is flying 50mph at you from 100+ feet high (e.g. chutes). The only thing protecting you from the feces in a plastic bag is a glove on your hands, no warning except the sound of the chute with a 60 pound bag flying towards your unprotected body with only gloves. And you could be unaware of knowing what hit you until you become awoken by a ghost.

review_title: OHSU is a good place to work, if you are extremely dedicated.
job_title: Research Assistant II in Portland, OR
pros: OHSU is on a hill west of Portland. It has beautiful views of the city, especially at night and the tram is a very nice way to get up and down the hill. Buses run late into the night which makes it easy to come up if you don't have a car. You also get an awesome discount on a trimet pass. The benefits are a major reason to consider OHSU. This being my first real job I was impressed by what they were offering me. OHSU is also a great learning environment and has a team atmosphere where you can ask all the questions you want and receive help. There are plenty of opportunities to advance in OHSU, either within your area or in another part of the hospital. They have every kind of program and research topic you can think of.
cons: Be prepared to work hard, depending on your role at the University or hospital, you will be working more than 50 hours a week - regularly.  Some days you will work 6 hours and others you will work 12.  Science does not have a 9-5 schedule.  It also takes a long time to commute.  Buses run often but it takes me 10 minutes in a car and at least an hour on 2 different buses.  Compensation is not the best but again this being my first job I did not expect much.  If you are in the research field as I am job security could be a concern, especially in this economy.

We are also part of the nursing union so we have good benefits because of that.
cons: The one thing I wish would change is I would love to have equal representation for holidays with the nurses. I wouldn't mind getting paid for a double back while working nights. That and nurses on call pay would be nice too. As a CNA you do not get this. But you still do get good representation because this hospital (mainly the Pediatric umbrella) really love and take care of their CNAs. If you are a hard worker you will be treated with respect and taken care of.

review_title: Is the commute and parking challenges worth it?
job_title: Senior Research Assistant in Portland, OR
pros: Some of the best reasons to work at OHSU is being in an environment that harbors world-renowned scientists- being a part of something big! The medical and dental benefits are good. The tri-met pass discount if phenomenal. I have a pretty good work-life balance, but as will be in my cons comments, sometimes my schedule is bound by public transportation schedules.
cons:
The worst thing about working at OHSU on Marquam hill is the commute. What should be a 20 min commute is a 40+ minute commute, at its best. My working hours revolve around the bus schedule. If I have to work non-standard hours driving is nearly impossible because of the lack of available parking and the high cost and bus schedules are limited to morning and evening, not mid day or night time.
There seems to be a high turn-over rate in human resources so it's nearly impossible to get anything done. You submit a request and they say they'll do it and two weeks later they're gone and it's another month before someone else comes in to replace them and then you have to submit the request all over again.
While the benefits are good, the pay is not very competitive.

review_title: HR and Poor Senior Management Weakens Organization
pros: Worked at OHSU Foundation. Good salary. Great benefits. If you have a good mgr, can be great place to work. OHSU's mission is def inspiring. Raising money for important causes and smart scientists is rewarding. Doernbecher mission is amazing. Location on Marquam (or downtown office) nice, easy to get to. Nice downtown office, remodeled recently.
cons:
HR is a joke -- they reward non-performers and create busy work for all. There are managers that everyone (including senior leaders and even HR) knows are bad at managing people, but they do nothing and even promote. Most employees don't go to HR anymore because we remember a few people who have been burned from going to them.

Biggest weakness is sr leadership.....lots of secrecy and annual reorgs. Closed door meetings and HR in the mix means "something is up," common phrase uttered by the cube class. Hahaha!! HR-senior management in cahoots with lots of crazy reorgs that create increasing levels of middle management. Some admins have 5 or 6 bosses -- alot for a place with 100 employees.

Doernbecher is a crazy storm. Turnover there is outrageous, yet leadership problems persist. Everyone knows about it too.

review_title: You think they are progressive - but they are NOT

Was not permitted to ask the compliance department questions directly (I was a coder) - again had to go up the chain of command.  Which begs the question, why have a compliance department?  If my supervisor is the one telling me to do something that is non - compliant and I have to go through them what's the point?

They seem to want people that are just going to be quiet and do what they are told even if it's wrong.

Started out as a flex- employee then hired full time but that came with a cut in pay because I was getting benefits.  I never took any benefits because I don't live in Oregon - and left at six months so was never eligible for employer match on retirement.

review_title: Great leaning opportunity with visible upward mobility but wish there was more training for managers
pros: It was a wonderful opportunity to network with professionals in the community and at the University. The donors and alumni are truly passionate about the cause and the next generation of students. The company is on the rise with their new Knight Cancer Campaign and they really do try to look within the company first to fill positions. A great place to work if you are interested in fundraising and event planning. So many of the people that work there are just delightful to work along side, especially those who are in administrative and assistant/associate directing positions.
cons: There isn't enough training and continued development for managers. There's a high turnover rate and burn out rate for administrative assistants. The voices of those who support aren't always heard or showed that they are valued. Everyone is very dedicated to the cause there but The flip side of this is that there is tunnel vision on only the end result. Understanding the importance of empowering everyone on a team can be overlooked. When everyone feels valued, acknowledged and challenged in a way that is meaningful for them, the team (and for that matter the company) can thrive. Their evaluation system is wonky as well. It doesn't appropriately capture the work that individuals do and sets employees up to be graded as mediocre.

review_title: Outstanding medical benefits package, but the size of the institution brings both perks and red tape.
pros: Lots of perks including discounts at various Portland businesses, a practically free bus pass, great medical insurance starting at no cost out of your pocket... and more importantly, they genuinely prioritize internal hires, so lateral as well as upward movement are anticipated, encouraged, and very common.
cons: Can be challenging if you're a problem solver/forward thinker in a low to mid-level position.  You get the sense that you have your role, and your job is to fulfill it-- "out of the box" thinking, or interest in pursuing opportunities beyond your defined position are pretty obviously blown off with a "Thanks for your feedback, I'll look into it," or a "well, that's really something that is handled more by the _____ department."

review_title: Difficult place for a non-medical professional
pros: Excellent compensation, education opportunities, great infrastructure
cons: May be "innovative" on the medical side (never worked at another hospital), but from what I saw, doctors and nurses were very reluctant to adopt new technologies on the administrative side. Poor training for managers and worked for very few good ones while there. HR is a robotic nightmare who take the manager's side in most conflicts. Union-busting/degredation is a pleasurable pastime for HR/Legal departments. Executive leadership is calcified, consultant depdendent and don't seem to know what's going on below their ivory towers. This is a giant organization-quit trying to get larger. Get good at what's already there. Quit ghetto-izing central services. Enough with the constant budget-scolding and every four year staff reductions. Ditch the outside consultants and gimmicky six sigma-esque programs. Spend the millions on training front line staff and managers.

review_title: Eh not a bad start if you’re leaving Starbucks.
pros: Benefits and pay is great, extremely competitive, weekends off are a nice perk.
cons: Bad communication with upper management and baristas, a lot of times I would come in on my usual scheduled shift just to find out they changed your times or someone called out and they “forgot to tell you”. Not much training or expanded coffee knowledge (even when they tell you you’ll be getting official Stumptown Training). Most days it was pretty hard to want to go to work because baristas get so stressed out and the hospital staff can be really rude sometimes, it becomes a very dull and stressful work environment. Paid vacation is really nice but as a new barista you won’t get the times you want because they have so many “senior baristas” and you compete with other cashiers for time off slots.

pros: I got a pay check every two weeks.
cons: It is very political and

pros: Nurse to patient ratio always stays within limits, mostly nurses are competent and friendly. A full time RN has to commit to work three days on a weekend in a month instead of typical four days.
cons: Chain of command is not followed, management does not follow a clear set of orders to apply to all staff therefore new employees are being left out, rules and regulations are not clear every person has their own different story about procedure. Management is not very professional and relies on he says she says basis when reprimanding.

review_title: A toxic work environment with lots of nepotism
pros: Work-life balance is superb. Great holiday and vacation time accruals. Great 403B plans if you choose the OHSU PPO instead of PERS. A nice Trimet stipend for transportation if you commute.
cons: The organization is so large that departments get lost in the shuffle and managers have limited to zero oversight. There is a lot of nepotism and people receive promotions based on favoritism instead of merit. Employee concerns are muted by management and there is no follow-up by HR. There is a bully culture that is not addressed. A lot of people are on cruise control until retirement and inefficient. Managers are incentivized to cut costs for their bonuses to the detriment of employees. There is an underbelly of a retaliation culture for those employees who do report concerns.

review_title: A large, bureaucratic, slow-moving "enterprise"  (review for IT only)
job_title: Senior Applications Systems Analyst in Portland, OR
pros: Benefits are great. Work-life balance is great. Lots of meetings and project managers adept at Gantt chart maintenance. If you are looking for a rigid, non-challenging, conflict-free and risk-averse experience then work here. OHSU IT is not cutting-edge or creative.
cons:
If you are not management then you have to pay dues to the AFSCME union. For some this won't be a "con" but it seems unusual for IT (when I started I was hourly and had to clock in/out, many of us are now union salaried). 

OHSU is able to straddle the razor of for-profit/non-profit, but there is a lot of money wasted. The right-hand often doesn't know what the left-hand is doing. It's not always clear who does (or is repsonsible for) what. Management would rather way overspend on outside vendors than take responsiblity in-house. A CYA mentality that would seem to require fewer employees, yet there are a lot if non-IT people in OHSU IT (that's the nicest way I can put it.)

There really is no entrepreneurial spirit at OHSU.

job_title: Research Assistant II in Portland, OR
pros: OHSU is a major employer in Portland and advances admirable medical research, training and care. I loved doing my small part to contribute to their mission. As a governmental, non-profit institution, OHSU treats employees quite well (great benefits packages) and working up on Marquam Hill as well as down at the South Waterfront offer beautiful settings.
cons: I sometimes felt part of the machine -- but it's unavoidable in such a large place. Lots of bureaucracy/delays in getting IT or custodial requests filled. But they do a good job of working with the resources they have. Low pay in research jobs at the assistant level.

review_title: Great place to work, but not for everyone
pros:
Dynamic environment. Lots of opportunities to learn and find action
Quasi public/private -- does a decent job of balancing a need for productivity and enforce accountability with a mission that's not only about money and a touch of a relaxed public vibe
Decent flexibility
cons:
Balkanized environment -- poor coordination across units and little sense of shared anything. Everyone looks out for their own local interests.
Resource allocation is all over the place. Some parts have money raining on them while others are truly suffering
Pay is also all over the place. Some highly skilled/trained people with very difficult jobs get paid very low while others really rake in the dough. This appears to be based more on how position was set up than on characteristics of the individual.
Success too often defined in terms of conformance with procedure rather than accomplishing anything real

pros: Great research and life-saving work performed at this facility. Hiring freeze to be lifted in March, which is great as OHSU continues its expansion at the waterfront. They try too stay competitive in pay and benefits, and pay for ONA and AFSCME is negotiated,
cons: Multiple cons. Our retirement plan was cut in half last year to save OHSU money.  Workers were given a 6% one time hourly increase with the suggestion to invest or save it. (Not all employees received the raise, either, so this led to resentment and divisiveness in the workplace.)  Many of us live paycheck to paycheck, so saving the 6% raise was not really possible. Most people I know already work 2 jobs just to make ends meet. Another issue: Management in my area openly lies to the workers  and discriminates against workers and applicants who do not share her immigrant background. We cannot complain to her superior as they are personal friends. We have to file claims with HR to try to get a fair resolution. Very discouraging.

job_title: Patient Access Specialist Resource in Portland, OR
pros: Pay, benefits, union , school reimbursement, transportation stipend,  reputable organization, Health
cons: Leadership, advancement, unorganized, it's not what you know-its who's butt you kiss or who you are friends with

review_title: Consolidation of power drives systematic exploitation of employees, students
pros: OHSU may be a fine place to work within the "missions" -- patient care or research. Even elsewhere, within administration and central services, the pay can be good.
cons: Within administration and central services, the name of the game is exploiting employees and students -- through rackets in benefits, parking, etc. -- to add a few extra bucks to OHSU's massive and massively increasing bottom line. Two executives now reign at a level that just a few years ago included nearly a dozen. These two have consolidated power and neutralized checks and balances. Go ahead and pledge your fealty to them if you have no problem lying and facilitating theft en masse from your colleagues.

job_title: Payroll Specialist II in Portland, OR
pros: Telecommute part time and raises were controlled by the union contract. Our office wasn't on the hill so we weren't forced to take the bus and didn't have a long wait list for a parking space. Easy to get a reserved space for ADA.
cons:
Difficult to get management to provide reasonable accommodation and adequate ergonomics in the desk set up. Telecommuting meant shared desk space in the office and not every coworker wanted to allow me to use my desk when we all needed to be in the office even though my headset was plugged into that specific desk and hard to move. For a hospital they could use better training on accommodating their employees with disabilities.

The schedule was not very flexible and some team members were allowed more flexibility than others.

pros: High quality clinical work in a collegial setting.  Beautiful small city that is easy to get arou nd, much like a small town. Spectacular lifestyle, but must not mind gray skies and drizzle! The relationship between clinical departments is wonderful. If you are very motivated you can go far. OHSU is a home for academic underachievers among medical schools. You can advance very far by publishing and pushing yourself a bit.
cons: Limitations in salary compared with other positions in other universities. This must be weighed against overall considerations of lifestyle. The city has much to enjoy. Your commute will not be difficult, generally. the occasional icy roads can be a bit treacherous. On a clear day there is no more beautiful place, but clear days are in the minority! The university is, like many state run institutions, subject to state budget cuts and loss of federal support. Most often, funding is at least adequate, however.

review_title: If you are in a department where you're appreciated, it is a fantastic place to work!
pros: There are great benefits! As a student, working in a vibrant research community and university is a huge plus. There's always an opportunity to learn something new and interesting people to network with! It's a friendly environment overall and many choose to make long term careers here.
cons: OHSU is a massive employer and as a result it can be painfully slow to get some things accomplished. There are also some departments that have less appreciation for the employees in service oriented roles. These individuals are the face of the department and often are the people that leave a lasting impression on visitors. The crazy scheduling and poor treatment can really have a dehumanizing effect and majorly impacts morale. Be kind to the cashiers, baristas, room service, and maintenance/custodial people you encounter.

pros: If your job is pretty squarely involved with patient care or research, you have a decent shot at doing good work to help people.
cons: The central administration and central services (HR, finance, integrity, communications, facilities, parking, food, and more) have grown increasingly corrupt as leadership has consolidated to two people instead of the former dozen competing warlords who checked and balanced each other. Key people in various departments actively collude to deceive employees and wring the most possible money from them, including automatic payroll deductions made under false pretenses.

review_title: Great place for slackers to work.
job_title: Senior Research Associate in Portland, OR
pros: OHSU contributes 12% of your salary to a retirement plan for you.  I have not come across any other research university that offers that kind of retirement compensation.  Also, you can earn up to 5 weeks vacation.
cons: There are a lot of dead weight employees working there.  These are people that most likely couldn't make it anywhere else.  The university hires them because their cheap.  OHSU needs to develop a better career path for junior researchers.  If you are a senior research associate working in a lab you will be doing the same job for the rest of your career.  The university should recruit some of these people into other positions.

review_title: Unprofessional upper management who say "LET THEM EAT CAKE!"
pros:
Gaining experience in a variety of areas for developing your career in healthcare.
Overall, great "on-service" medical teams family medicine & general medicine physician teams
cons:
Depending on the unit you work, most shifts experience with extremely difficult patient demographics (ie: constant physical, verbal and emotional abuse)

Benefits USED to be reasonable...though every year they are diminishing and changing policies, increasing deductibles, and percentage of employee payout ( for the worse), and dropping features and services.

HORRIBLE "off service" unprofessionalism from specialty service physicians.

Worst of all? Unprofessional management who is completely out of touch with the realities of day to day operations.

review_title: Employer no longer contributes to pension
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Marquam Hill, OR
pros: Good place to work; competitive pay and benefits, but benefits are not what they used to be. Great place for young workers.
cons: Down graded retirement benefits so employer no longer contributes the 6%. Started with the PERS program, and will shift to the UPP program in Jan 2016. The UPP covered employees will get a pay increase that the PERS members did not to offset this change. OHSU is also repeatedly encouraging long time employees to retire; does not value loyalty from its long term employees. Has raised its premiums for Kaiser medical and Kaiser dental insurances to prohibitively high rates. Only the most senior long time employees have Kaiser insurance.

review_title: Decent pay but Poor Work/Life balance
pros: It really depends on the department you work in. If you work with providers, you get many perks - free lunches, free coffee/tea, Holiday parties, employee appreciation gifts. Pay is average, benefits as well. Rewarding when you walk out feeling like you made a difference in a patient's life.
cons: If however you work behind the scenes in administrative/operations, you are basically the red-headed stepchild of the organization. Overlooked/overworked. Turnover has been an issue, which puts more strain on the people that stick around. Our breakroom sits 4 people for a department of 100+, not even coffee or silverware is supplied.  Management disrespectful and shows favoritism, and does not communicate in an amicable way. Commute sucks 10 hours out of the week, even though I could do my job entirely from home.

review_title: Great at patient healthcare, bad at business and internal functions, low wages (for non-union).
pros:
Surrounded by very bright people.
Everyone seems to share a genuine interest in the care of patients.
Flexibility within many departments.
cons:
Very slow to get things done and make changes.
Departments are "silos". While communication has improved, each department operates under its own business model, and without common direction and goals.

pros: You will find some terrific co-workers and colleagues.  The Hill Campus makes for lovely walks during break times.  As a union worker, the work/life balance can't be beat....unless you have to commute on/off the hill (which most people do)....then daily life can be very burdensome.
cons: Management - Union is very much Us vs Them.  The culture is non-communicative, demeaning, task oriented.  If you like to sit around and get paid for not doing much, you might like it here.  The culture promotes a very mediocre level of performance.  There are few repercussions/rewards for doing either good OR bad work.  Just sit in your cubicle for another year and you will get the same raise as everyone else.  Surprisingly few opportunities to advance and develop as a professional.

pros: I came into this position with a lot of experience using the system OHSU (the university side) uses, so it wasn't a difficult transition. My boss trusts that I know how to do my job without micromanaging me, but is available to help whenever it is needed.
cons: OHSU loves to use paper when most other schools have adopted electronic databases, which makes everyone's job much more inefficient. OHSU puts all of their focus and money into the hospital, and doesn't give much to the university side. We have outdated programs/general processes/offices, and change comes very slowly, as our efficiency is not seen as a priority.

review_title: An exciting place to work that cares about your development!
job_title: Research Assistant I in Portland, OR
pros:
It all depends on what lab you work for. I loved my boss, my team, and my office, and feltl very supported - but it's all lab specific. I worked in the Department of Psychiatry. My lab really cared about its employees' career development.
OHSU is very exciting and I appreciate the free Lynda classes and Grand Rounds I was been able to attend. I felt proud to work at an organization that was so dedicated to diversity and fair treatment.
cons:
The pay was kind of bad. Not very competitive - I ultimately exited the research career because of the poor salaries.
Parking is awful and expensive. If you work on the hill, park at the Schnitzer lot and take the shuttle to the tram (or walk) and then tram it up. It'll save you a few dollars.

review_title: A great place to work as long as you don't think about it too much.
job_title: Computer User Support Analyst III in Portland, OR
pros:
great benefits, although the union is currently bargaining, so who knows what will happen. My department offers very flexible hours and I work in a more isolated environment where I am able to hide from the daily bull crap that goes on in the rest of the university.
Oh yeah, and they have a super expensive tram with no climate control.
cons:
Poor executive leadership.
Hypocritical upper level managers/division directors
People making decisions for others without considering the needs of people doing the work.
Joe Robertson's stupid emails talking about budget crisis when he owns three homes and got a $1million + bonus last year.

review_title: Great place to work and learn
pros: work in all areas of the hospital, learn from incredible colleagues and physicians that want to serve their patients and teach the best medicine possible to new medical providers , as well as work as a team to provide the best care possible to patients.
cons: sometimes you feel undervalued or attacked by corporate during negotiations, along with hiring and pay issues leaving departments short handed during the worst times of year, while executives and other non provider positions are getting raises and bonuses...but for the most part they are fair if you block out the bureaucracy of the place... and really this is what poisons medicine and the progress of health care and educating the best in brightest in the country... but they will never see it that way...but you cant help but love caring for people and that is easy here!

pros: It's a big and broad research community -- there's a lot of exciting work being done here. The size of the employee community helps ensure good representation with the management.
cons: I don't work on the hill currently, but have in the past. That can be tough if your schedule is demanding, as you are at the mercy of our admittedly excellent public transportation system. My position is with at what used to be Oregob Graduate Institute. Now that it has been eaten up by OHSU, we are all a little concerned with the long-term viability of our non-medical programs. So far, OHSU seems to be happy to bring us into the school of medicine without requiring massive changes in our research mission, but not all of our programs have been so lucky.

review_title: Excellent employer, suffers from low public-sector pay
job_title: Research Assistant I in Beaverton, OR
pros:
Excellent retirement benefits (12% employer contribution for unclassified employees)
Excellent health benefits (basic medical, dental and vision plans are free; medical plan has a low deductible and low out-of-pocket max)
Excellent PTO
Interesting projects
Good job security
Good community and generally positive view of leadership
cons: Non-competitive pay (I could get a 75% raise with the same job title if I were willing to move into private industry/out of the Portland area)

review_title: Great benefits, unless you're outside of Portland
job_title: Research Assistant II in Washougal, WA
pros: Large university hospital and access to many opportunities to learn something new or advance your career. Benefits packages are pretty good and lots of fun events and ways to meet new people. Main campus on the hill has stunning views of Portland.
cons: Working off-campus in Vancouver gives you extremely limited access to many of the good benefit programs available to employees in Portland. Medical is cheap, but if you live/work too far away from the main campus you have to enroll in the more expensive plan, or take nearly the entire day off to attend one appointment.

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Portland, OR
pros: Salary & Benefits, Pay raise twice a year
cons: PARKING, Management Communication, On boarding, MA ability to work remotely

review_title: Very union driven, but overall it was ok
pros: The medical directors care about the quality of work, which for me is key. The upper management in the labs underwent a significant change, thankfully right as I was leaving as they became very bottom line focused and rather than caring about the outcome for the patients. I have heard this has gotten better though since I left and a few of the upper management team were let go. Most of my coworkers were really great people and I made life long friends while working there.
cons: No way to get a better salary due to the unions. Everyone gets the same pay and raises no matter their job performance. Very busy and often understaffed.

pros:
From what I can tell OHSU is an excellent organization. I was hired as a new graduate nurse and have worked here for 6 months so far. 

As a teaching hospital, they have cultivated a culture that promotes learning and self-improvement. I would highly recommend it for a new graduate, or someone who values an atmosphere of supportiveness. I can't speak for other departments, but the pediatric emergency department is an incredible place to work. From the manager down, they really employ great people. Almost everyone is friendly, knowledgable, and more than willing to help if you need it. The people I work with make a stressful job much more bearable and I'm extremely grateful for that. 

As far as pay and benefits go, I have to say I was awestruck when I learned about their starting pay. Currently it's 37.02 an hour for all new nurses (0 years of experience with a BSN). And it goes up every year, all the way to 54 dollars an hour. Coming from Missouri where the starting pay was about 20.50 an hour at most hospitals, this news was a surprise. But that's what you get with a nursing union though. The differentials are impressive as well. There is a 6.00 dollar night differential, 2.30 evening differential, and a 3.70 weekend differential. There are also a multitude of other differentials depending on the circumstance. 

On top of the compensation, the benefits are impressive too. Full personal medical, dental and vision coverage if you are a full-time employee (0.7 FTE or greater) at no cost to you. There are several options regarding the types of benefits you can choose from and some do cost money. Retirement options at OHSU are excellent as well. You can choose from an state-run self funded pension plan or an employer contribution plan that essentially pays you 12% of your earnings a year to an investment plan, plus a self-funded portion. 

So far OHSU has more than met my expectations of a positive employment experience. I would absolutely recommend it to other nurses.
cons:
The worst part of the job is it can be very stressful, especially if you are new and inexperienced. Again I can't speak for other departments, so this downside is likely specific to the department I'm in. As you can imagine children can be a difficult population to care for given their lack of understanding and fear of strange people and places. Add into it parents who are panicked because their child is sick, and you can get into some fairly difficult situations. So ultimately, the job is physically, mentally, and emotionally taxing. 

Aside from that the only downside to OHSU is it's location. The state income tax in Oregon is one of the highest in the nation. So about 31.5% of my paychecks go towards taxes (FIT, SIT, WC, and SS). Living in and around Portland is expensive as well, at least compared to suburban/urban Missouri. The commute into and out of Portland is awful as well, if you work normal hours (8:00am-5:00pm). Luckily I work at night an avoid traffic for the most part. 

Lastly parking near OHSU "up on the hill" is very expensive (14 dollars a day) and can be very frustrating if parking spots are limited. Parking is free at night though. 

Overall the pros outweigh the cons and I would highly recommend this organization.

job_title: Senior Research Assistant in Portland, OR
pros: There are a few brilliant minds trying to make OHSU a great place. It is variable from manager to manager but seems to be a fairly good focus on work-life balance. OHSU tries to create employee incentives to be healthy. Good dental coverage.
cons:
1) The parking situation is a nightmare. Yes OHSU incentives and subsidizes public transport but this is not enough. The wait-list is long and employees most in need of parking will never get parking.
2) Limited shared resources 
 3) If involved in Knight Cancer Research, disagree with the KCRB building design. The design for modern, wide-open, flexible space is adapted from the tech industry and is an outdated trend. Not to mention it will not facilitate good science.
4) Nightmare during inclement weather

review_title: OHSU was a decent employer.  I thought it would've been a better experience overall.
pros: The prestige and benefit package .  They have a great 403b.  OHSU has such a good reputation in the community that it looks good on my resume.   There are some good people there.
cons: My manager was very inexperienced. There was lack of nursing leadership.  Poor communication overall.  The pay was less than other hospitals in the area.  Nursing has a union which I think is both good and bad at the same time.  Nurses that are not so great great tend to be allowed to stay in the system because it's hard to fire them or discipline them without union involvement.

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Beaverton, OR
pros: I was absolutely in love with the level of respect all providers had toward each other & students alike. no one hesitated to answer questions or teach more about a subject to any inquiring mind. the definition of what a teaching hospital should be.
cons: i n t e n s e patient flow, population, level of required care and expectations to be met. at least in my clinic, management was the single WORST experience I have ever had in a working job. beyond disrespectful to employees and patients alike. disregarded anything that did not fit with their personal agenda; they hardcore played favorites and be prepared if you cross any one of those favorites - you will be singled out and harassed beyond tolerance.

job_title: Research Assistant II in Portland, OR
pros:
Great opportunities for medical students or those looking to advance their career
Highly innovative and intelligent community
Good benefits, includes transit pass
cons:
As a competitively ranked teaching hospital OHSU recognizes that if you are not willing to bend over backward for them, there are plenty of other medical students who gladly will
Very unprofessional culture
Lacks common diversity and inclusion practices 
Many research positions are non unionized
Each department seems to operate on their own terms, not as part of a bigger organization
Discussions about revenue often take precedent over healthcare


I have personally not received any of the project bonuses I was promised upon being hired (specific to research)

review_title: Takes care if their employees, but still a bureaucracy
job_title: Room Service Associate in Portland, OR
pros:
The work was rewarding, many of my co-workers were passionate, hard-working people. OHSU provides great benefits, designed to make it very possible to gain skills, and increase your prospects while employed. Further, the mission statement and policies have no-tolerance harassment and completely inclusive of family members and partners (before the law caught up).
 Once you have a job here, even at the bottom of the totem pole, it is very possible to work your way up, and get an education while working.  It will take time.
cons: Middle management can be condescending, or sticklers for unimportant (non performance related) details. However, in any entry level position that will be true, and the benefits and great policies overall make up for it.

pros: good work ethic and collegial. There are some exceptional individuals who are working on some cutting edge stuff. The University also works with local hi-tech companies and other universities such as Portland State and Oregon State. This gives an opportunity to explore areas that otherwise are hard to come by
cons: Career growth is stunted as many folks work for long time and new openings aren't created that often. This creates a situation where years on job is given a disproportionate share of credit over creativity and dynamism. Since this is an academic medical center, the dice is loaded in favor of health care professionals and those in other careers have to live with it.

review_title: Pleasant place to work, but parking is horrible on the hill.
job_title: Research Assistant II in Portland, OR
pros: This varies widely depending on where you work and what capacity you work in within the hospital. I worked in research and enjoyed it. Fortunately I worked with great people. Also, I enjoyed the food options there and the campus is beautiful during the warmer months.
cons: Unless you are there 5+ years, good luck getting a parking pass. If you drive, want to park at work and are relatively new there you will need to fork $10 a day to park on the hill. I spent a fortune working there for a year. Charging employees the same high rate as anyone else is very unfortunate.

pros: Magnet certified, union represented (look on ONA's website for the entire contract, under AURN, which lists compensation tables, etc), competitive pay ($35.23 starting pay for no experience with BSN), 4.8 weeks vacation to start (increasing every 5 years to a max of 7.22 after 20 years), compensation for certification, greatly subsidized bus pass ($50 for a YEARLY pass right now - an $1100 value!), beautiful views, great food (including a natural mini grocery store), bike valet, Tillikum bridge (coming soon!), cash compensation for bike commuters, almost 100% covered medical benefit (dental about $150/mo for family, I pay $7 a month for my whole family's medical), 12% employer contribution to retirement plan w/o required employee match OR access to PERS (or whatever pers is called these days - OPSRP?? - a defined *benefit* program, not a defined *contribution* program) with employee required contribution of 6%, annual 2.25% cost of living raise in addition to annual raise, tuition reimbursement, mostly nice and friendly people, HUGE emphasis on diversity, everyone works every other weekend (might be considered a con but it makes it fair for everyone and with seniority you can request more off.  Comes with a 10% weekend differential), unit based practice counsels, lots of free continuing ed opportunities.  This company expects a lot but I think gives a lot in return.
cons: Usual corporate bs, usual trappings of nursing culture (worse depending on unit - not enough staff, nurses eating young, etc), parking is $13 a day and there is a several year waiting list for annual passes (which you still have to pay $13 a day for - you're just guaranteed a spot that way), teaching hospital (which is rad, because you get to see and learn a lot, but also you have to deal with new residents every. single. year.)

job_title: Research Integrity Specialist in Portland, OR
pros: Pay is competitive and the benefits are decent. The prescription prices are amazing and I get 15 vacation days a year in addition to sick leave and holidays. The work hours are somewhat flexible and they are going to start a new policy that will allow us to work from home 1 day each week. Great retirement and it's all in a beautiful area/campus.
cons: Less vacation than most colleges and no time off for spring break (not bad compared to most jobs but less compared to most other colleges). Budget cuts have lost us a lot of resources and manpower we would have had otherwise. Also, there is some degree of bureaucracy and red tape involved.

job_title: Research Assistant II in Portland, OR
pros: Lots of great people to work with.  Being healthy and balancing home and work is encouraged.  CWE has a lot of great employee development courses.  Beautiful facilities and lots of job opportunities.
cons: In some ways the organization is just too big.  Big names draw in big donations but little thought given to support structure to grow and support the resources.  A lot of duplicated efforts and silos.  The tuition discount is disappointing.  Parking is a nightmare - at least a 5 year wait to park on the hill, make sure you live near public transportation lines and budget that time into your commute.

review_title: Great mission. Great environment. Mediocre pay.
pros: Academia, but feels applied because so much research directly applies to the clinical practice there. Great staff support and benefits. Good management, and room for advancement. Depending on where you end up, you can expect good work-life balance.
cons: As in all academia, the pay is lower than in industry, and money is always in short supply. Most projects find continuous fundign. But sometimes soft money can run out.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Portland, OR
pros: There are some really good researchers and good teachers within the residency programs.
cons:
Unfortunately OHSU is run like a fiefdom, and even within departments where there is a clinical side and an education element, they are at odds, as everything is driven by the clinical dollars, with education getting a shoddy second place.  The institution is way too top heavy with administrators who are inflexible and lack any vision other than whatever their excel spreadsheet shows them for the monthly revenue.   There tends to be a lot of lip service, but the institution only gets behind any research initiative after it has received plenty grants and outside kudos.  
The investment the institution makes in any real career development is practically nil.  For years, their Career Development Center was made up of one person, who had only part-time administrative help.

review_title: great, if you're an MD or cancer researcher
pros: Beautiful campus with a lot of talented people. Great research facilities, support, and cores. If you are looking to be a biomedical scientist in the Portland area, this is pretty much your only option.
cons: Parking is worse than terrible. You will not park on the hill. Food is expensive. There is a definite lean toward cancer based research (for obvious reasons). Being in a neuroscience based lab, I often felt like our research didn't matter to the university.

review_title: Wages are underwhelming, but benefits are great.
job_title: Research Assistant II in Portland, OR
pros: The benefit package is pretty nice.  They contribute an amount equal to 12 percent of your salary to retirement, have excellent medical coverage, and a lot of vacation/sick time (if you aren't in the union).
cons: There are very few parking spots and you have to wait between 5 and 8 years to even get one, then once you do you have to pay 100 dollars a month for it.  Taking the bus can take way too long unless you live close and waiting at a bus stop in the rain sucks.  The wages for research staff are pretty low, union wages are ok but you get a lot less vacation time.

pros: Some chances for advancement and pay is excellent.  Peers are very competent in their specialties.  Incentives for healthy life choices are plentiful.
cons: There is no vision or mission statement for IT.  IT as a whole lacks leadership and direction; OHSU is constantly behind the curve when it comes to technology.  The culture is severely dysfunctional and people are more worried about playing politics and appeasing others than doing what's best for the patient.

review_title: No direction, no communication, no collaboration
pros: Most individuals were pleasant and helpful.
cons: OHSU took over my department from an affiliate (Tuality). You’d think this would be a step up for us, but it was miserable. No direction from executive leadership. Managers were given conflicting and inconsistent direction. There was no collaboration: it often seemed like we were pitted against one another. No communication/coordination between OHSU and Tuality leadership on common projects. Many (not all) OHSU staff were uninterested in productivity or customer satisfaction, and management seemed uninterested in changing that. Thousands of dollars were tossed away each month because OHSU was unable to implement its infrastructure; these economies of scale were supposed to save money.  To be fair, I’m not sure it’s ITG’s fault as much as the OHSU executive leadership,who leapt into the Tuality relationship with seemingly no regard for the cost or complexity of integrating these systems.

pros: OHSU has a fantastic mission and contributes directly to the overall health and well being of others.  The people are fantastic and passionate about their work.  I feel that I can do great work here.
cons: Culturally OHSU has a hard time enforcing standards and best practices.  Sometimes this is needed in order to make improvements and move to the next level of maturity.  Our entrepreneurial culture can be at odds with this goal and results in some maverick process and behavior that isn't addressed.

review_title: ONPRC is a wonderful part of OHSU that invests in its employees
job_title: Research Assistant II in Beaverton, OR
pros:
~Great staff and atmosphere 
~Monumentally beneficial research succeeding with top investigators
~Interesting presentations and lectures that employees are encouraged to attend
~Great benefits, lots of vacation/sick time, 
~Implements "carrot not stick" approach to health- offering discounted insurance rate and cash to participate in healthy behavior like company paid Weight Watchers or logging workouts
~Approachable upper management
~Social events held for employees promotes strong community 
~Progressive company- equal rights for same sex marriages/partnerships
cons:
~Academic research does not pay well (unless you are running the lab- sometimes) 
~Necessary use of animal models for research

job_title: Research Assistant II in Portland, OR
pros: Researchers labs seem to have a very laid back attitude which makes for a very comfortable work environment but does not produce optimal productivity. Communication within departments is good but institution level interactions are rare. Commuting options are excellent, even providing monetary incentives ride your bike to work (how Portland!). Nice view.
cons: Cumbersome institutional administration, little social interaction within my department. Good research fills a niche but is not cutting edge or exciting as that going on elsewhere. Focus is definitely more on the hospital side of the operation (ie the moneymaker) rather than research side. Came to feel more like a 9 to 5 commitment than an engaging pursuit.

review_title: The good ole boys are still in charge.
job_title: Assistant Professor of Nursing in Portland, OR
pros: reputation, proximity of educational and clinical buildings (hospital), research activity, variety of educational programs
cons: rigidly hierarchical, physician-dominated, with an anachronistic emphasis on empire-building versus caring for people. We do not need more towering glass buildings! Monuments to the money-makers are not progress.

pros:
1. Good benefit (less burden for family health and dental insurance)
2. Small but strong research environment
3. Environment in Portland is very good (weather, nature, air, water and so on)
4. Public transportation in Portland is very good (Bus, subway)
cons:
1. Living cost (eg. house rent) is getting increased due to the increased population
2. Information about recent technology and research trend is lacking
3. For the salary increase, we need to talk to our PI ever year. It is not increased automatically. If we don't say anything, the salary is the same.

review_title: It is a good place to work.
pros: The city is good and very beautiful. The University campus is close to downtown and very convenient for life. The hospital is also very excellent. For people who want to study medical science and want to be doctors, it is a good place to work.
cons: The university is a medical school. So most of resouces are focusing on medicine science and medical treatment. The biomedical engineering is relatively not strong.

review_title: Good benefits, many opportunities, lot of exciting work.
pros: Cutting edge research and medical care. Also houses schools of medicine, nursing, pharmacy, and ophthalmology. For a large organization it's  pretty well-run. Quick hiring process. They have an excellent reputation throughout the state. The benefits, for now, are generous. Good workforce development commitment.
cons:
Pay is not competitive. Research doesn't compensate for prior years of professional experience. 
Battles with union contracts at the same time that the top six executives received over $600,000 dollars in annual bonuses, and the organization was trumpeting their most profitable year ever.

review_title: Great bennies may make up for lack of organization and leadership.
pros: Colleagues are generally friendly.  The pay is much better than the VA Hospital next door, and the benefits are great.  They offer 11% contribution to your 401k, without you having to put anything towards it yourself.
cons: The department I worked for lacked in its ability to identify problems.  The physicians were very busy, very good at what they did, but seemed to not leave time to really handle organizational and non-physician staff problems.

review_title: Creative Web Development opportunities very limited
pros: Originally I had a full-time position and left it to take an hourly temporary position. I sacrificed longer-term stability, benefits and job security for flexibility... but gained ultimately flexibility including the ability to telecommute (work from home or almost anywhere with internet access).
cons: As a temporary hourly employee, sometimes I don't get work for months. Obviously this can be rough and requires me to get other work or be able to manage a grossly fluctuating income. Before 2014 it also meant being responsible for my own health care coverage. In terms of the work itself, I am under-utilized and unsure of how to get more work, and/or more creative work, within OHSU.

review_title: Rare to find a good job
job_title: Public Service Representative in Portland, OR
pros: Pay is decent and the vacation/holidays are hard to beat. Plus you can get a public transportation annual pass for $50.
cons: Very few departments are respected and there is so much politics. I would expect to have negative interactions with some of the visitors because it is a hospital and typically people aren't there for happy reasons but honestly the employees were the worst. Rude and disrespectful--you need to be very cut throat and at an executive level to enjoy your work at OHSU.

pros:
In the department that I work in, I get a lot of flexibility in terms of working hours and work-life balance. We can come into work any time of the day as long as we work our 8 hour shift. So I can come in at 6:30am and leave at 3pm, to beat the traffic. Others with children, usually come in around 8 or 9am and leave around 5pm or 6pm. 

Health/Dental/Vision insurance is pretty cheap. I pay about $3 a month for just me. There is a $25 co pay for each office visit, with an annual deductible of $1,600. 

Management: I am very fortunate to have a great director. He has to deal with a lot of the political non sense happening at the university, but he does a great job in leading our department. I'm not sure I can say that about some of the other departments here at OHSU.
cons:
The annual deductible could be lower. OHSU is a hospital so you'd think that their health benefits would be tremendous. 

No paid maternity leave. You must use all of your vacation and sick time after giving birth. Once those are depleted, you must take unpaid leave. 

OHSU is VERY political. Departments and department heads will get ahead if they schmooze the right people. 

Parking. The parking situation here is atrocious. OHSU deems parking as a luxury and a profit-making portion of their company. A monthly parking pass costs $190. AND there's a 3-year waiting list, at least for the main Marquam Hill Campus. If you work on the south waterfront, you can find local businesses to give you a pass for around $75-$90. So a lot of employees either ride their bikes to work or take public transport. OHSU offers an annual trip-met pass for about $60.

It is well known in the area that OHSU underpays its staff, with the exception of the physicians and researchers. This could be improved on.

review_title: Politics thru the roof - so sad, it's not about health care
pros: Benefits - they do offer a lot of benefits.
cons: Politics. Most places have politics, but this place is above and beyond. Many, many incompetent people in leadership positions, huge turnover rate in management and some leadership positions. Culture overall is a joke, many departments have their own culture cause the greater culture is bad. I worked in all aspects (health care, research, and academics) and it's the same overall. When the President and the CEO of the hospital are in a constant power struggle, and a CFO that clearly states he would like to close the emergency room to keep out the indignant patients who don't have insurance, what message does this send the staff?

pros: Good hours and great people.  It's also a beautiful city with a great public transit system.  I take a bus to a train to a tram and overlook a great view of the city
cons: Low salary and slow corporate climb.  I've been working here for over 20 years and the pay goes up and down.  I even lost all my sick leave as I retired for a year and came back

job_title: Medical Laboratory Scientist in Portland, OR
pros: My coworkers are pretty awesome. Union give everyone pretty good protection. By comparing with hospitals around, pay is about in the middle.
cons: Terrible supervisor. Supervisor seems has nothing to do all day; sitting in office play with phone. Also, supervisor like to ask everyone opinions about issues, the only problem is action never taken, issues never resolved only getting worst, yet you will be asked about your options about these issues again and again for years. It is very unprofessional, Very disrespectful of your time. This is just the tip of an iceberg.

review_title: A place of growth for many!
job_title: Web Specialist II in Marquam Hill, OR
pros: OHSU truly cares about its employees. I started as a temp, was mentored into a full time direct hire that lasted 9 years during which my salary more than tripled. They invested in my education, provided an amazing 401k, and unbeatable health benefits.
cons: OHSU is huge, expect many cross functional reporting heirarchies. To thrive here you need a collaborative team spirit that overcomes authority hurdles as a project may affect many governing groups for different reasons. To get things done, you will want to network and connect with many teams outside of your reporting structure.

review_title: Great and friendly place to work, but offers a very expensive insurance.
pros: It is a hospital campus with research involved. I worked at one of the research buildings and I liked it. People are friendly and hardworking for sure. It is a very clean environment. I should also add that it is a very competitive place to work at. I see that as a good thing. They encourage their employees to live a healthy life by promoting cheaper insurance in return of proven active life.
cons: The insurance they offer is very expensive and they do not accept every other insurances to start working there. At least that is how it was.

pros: Excellent benefits, vacation accrual is average. Coworkers were fun to be around. I really enjoyed working here in the beginning.
cons: HEAVY micromanaging. Manager playing favorites. Low hourly pay even with years of experience, they start your pay at the bottom of the totem pole. No union protection until you reach your 6 months. Seems like every suggestion on how to make the clinic run better was given a heavy no response. Taking time off and feeling guilty about it.

pros: Good work life balance, great benefits, community discounts, great people and it's awesome to be part of an organization that always has interesting research being conducted.
cons: Despite supposedly having "preference" for applying to jobs internally, myself and others that I have spoken to have actually found it very difficult to move into a new position within the organization. There's even rules based on the union agreement about getting interviews for internal candidates with preference that some hiring managers don't abide by.

review_title: High ambitions. Too much red tape
pros: Good mission that strives for excellence. A lot of truly driven employees that want to make a difference in the lives of their patients
cons: There isn't enough collaboration between some of the educational programs and the hospital. There is a huge opportunity that is being missed here

review_title: Not the best place to work
job_title: Senior Research Associate in Portland, OR
pros: Great place to learn for students. Creative atmosphere. Plenty of $ now (billion $ challenge) but many recent dept cuts for streamlining programs so be careful
cons: Parking is expensive and has a long waiting list. Exclusive to researchers: Low pay compared to other academic industries. Will lay you off without batting an eye or lending assistance to find another job. (Even after nearly 20 years with the company!). ABSOLUTELY no room for advancement unless you work under a big wig, regardless of how hard you work or how successful you have been.

job_title: Research Assistant II in Portland, OR
pros: The company has decent benefits (paid parental leave starting in 2019!). I have a flexible work schedule, and a supportive direct supervisor.
cons: The politics in the upper levels of management often pit one department/unit interests against other departments, which doesn't help build a strong community overall. Also, the company can be very focused on how they show up externally (from a PR perspective), at the expense of internal functionality and employee satisfaction.

review_title: Very autonomous labs working largely on physiologicy
pros: Huge number of resources with faculty members who are very well established and experts at what they do. The emphasis of research is largely on physiology and what seems to be, translational research.
cons: Situated in a part of Portland that us distant from the human race. The research questions, while being diverse, are too focussed on translational science focussed making it a but of a bore for those interested in more of a basic science research,

job_title: Room Service Associate in Portland, OR
pros: Excellent benefits, compensation, regular communication with employees, culture of care, professionalism, friendly staff, one of the best medical research centers on earth. You can be paid to ride your bike to work. 65% off TriMet pass.
cons: Overburdened with middle management, service and support level employees do as little as possible, massive waste, understaffed, dubious oversight of relationships with other organizations and governments, regular spats with unions. Elevators take too long. Permanent state of upgrade/construction.

review_title: They expect people to "volunteer" or work for free, and there for the wages are grossly inadequate.
pros: Benefit package, interactions with other like minded colleagues
cons: Grossly underpaid positions, lack of respect for students and residents who pay to be there and learn (has affected how much grads want to give back once they leave), Many people in their 70's who either volunteer or work for a very low wage, which leads to the expectations you will be hired for pennies on the dollar when you have over 11 years of education....

pros: Doing good for the community, advancing research - their heart is in the right place.
cons: Non-union employees' compensation suffers because OHSU has to afford higher pay for union members.  Constant budget cuts and trying to do more with less has been wearing on everyone for a while now and is almost at a breaking point.  Everyone's too busy, so no clear goals or focused efforts - just constant firefighting and chaos.

job_title: Sterile Supplies Manager in Portland, OR
pros: They have a good mission and it is more than a job. The department I worked in was doing important, valuable work to benefit all of us.
