cons: The working conditions can be pretty grim, and without a union they would be a lot worse. It's such a big institution that you are seen as an employee unit, not a person, and they can just grind you down.

review_title: Can be a good place to work, if you can find your role
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Portland, OR
pros: Good science is being done here - there is a strong spirit of collaboration and sharing among researchers of different disciplines.
cons: It's a large organization - if you are trying to work across departments, it can be difficult to get things done. Departmental regulations do not really help.

review_title: Room to Grow, learn, and diversify
pros: Big university, unique combination of academia/research/clinical settings, lots of departments and specialties to help with policy and procedure, if you get in good with a decent department then they can make room for you to grow
cons: Sometimes too restrictive in policies and procedures. The running joke is that you need to form 3 committees to decide if you should add another committee so things can be slow moving to change.

review_title: A not highly demanding work environment where a premium is placed on "work-life balance"
pros: The people are committed and competent generally, and care about the mission of the organization.
cons: In IT, the groups are silo'ed, money is tight, and there is by necessity a much higher value placed on keeping the lights on than on innovating.

pros:
Living in Portland is great
Great public transit benefit
Although not ethnically/racially diverse (because Portland is fundamentally white), it is socially diverse
Send out notices often about changes going on in the university
cons:
Although not explicitly stated, they are downsizing basic research, focusing more on applied medical research (they call it "increasing efficiencies"). For this reason, many basic research labs are leaving or closing, as the policies implemented make labs and departments pay more for University services than they used to (i.e. pay rent for conference rooms or regular cleaning of floors), funding is scarcer, and PI's get restrictions on their lab space as soon as an RO1 does not go up for renewal (at least in some departments).
There is only a budding post-doc association, which is to be commended for their efforts in improving post-doc life.
They are very fishy about the salary for post-docs. They only advertise the NIH recommended levels, but I know we don't get paid that, and I don't know how are salary increases are calculated (again, not as per NIH standards).
In general, and this is my impression and not necessarily a shared one, is that they talk a big talk, but when it comes down to it, they view employees as worker bees. They get away with it because people like living in Portland.
Benefits are not very good for post-docs, but that might be the case in most institutions. I don't know how it is for regular employees.
CUlture and values is rated poorly before, not because of the people (I think there is a great culture here) but because the values stated by the institution are one thing, but the reality is another.

pros: Loved the atmosphere and my team was great.
cons: I had an overall good experience numerous years and then all the layoffs continued to occur and all additional work continued to get piled on and we were not to work OT.  The expectations from Management increased however realistically it was very unreasonable.

job_title: Senior Research Assistant in Portland, OR
pros: Because OHSU is so large, those in the research departments get a lot of infrastructure support.  There is support with contract negotiations, grant setup and closing, and IRB applications are pretty smooth.  Benefits are also very good.  Very generous vacation and sick time, and the health insurance is more than adequate for a 20-something.
cons: Research jobs vary drastically since researchers get a lot of independence with their labs.  Because of this, there may be a good deal of disconnect (with researcher staff in the same department not knowing what other labs are doing).

job_title: Senior Research Assistant in Portland, OR
pros: Smart and dedicated scientists. Culture on the bottom tiers is great, I enjoy the fostering of collaboration. There is a lot of great science coming out of OHSU.
cons: Pay is robbery. When I think of all the money I've lost working for this institution I want to cry. Many employees have low moral and do not feel valued. Very high turnover.

review_title: Its a great place to work
pros: 3 weeks paid vacation, really good benefits overall (20 days/year of sick time, matched 401K, disability and maternity leave, and Aetna health insurance with decent PPO plan, dental & vision)
cons: Parking is terrible! As an employee you can be put on a waiting list to get to park in a parking lot which is about 2-3 years (and then you still have to paid about  $100 a month or more depending on where the lot is located). Otherwise you can park on the street which is 2hr parking and they patrol/ticket constantly.

review_title: Good but not great - keep your head down
pros: Decent healthcare and retirement benefits.  Once you're in, you can somewhat easily transfer around the University.  Some departments have flexible schedule or telecommuting options.  Transportation incentives including bike riding & transit passes.
cons: Parking is a joke - a 7 year wait list for the privilege of forking over $165 a month.  Management is hit or miss depending upon the department, but overall the bureaucracy is stifling.  Management is constantly trying to whittle away at employee benefits - less healthcare, lowering pay scales, no more retirement contributions.

job_title: Clinical Nurse Coordinator, Hematologic Malignancies in Portland, OR
pros: Other departments might provide a better working environment, good salary and benefits, good public transit options, scenic campus.
cons: Top down leadership environment that retaliates against nurses/women who report patient safety issues or abusive treatment by providers. Current nursing and faculty leadership of CHM/CHH are not patient centered, and significant decisions are driven by ego and power/control issues. There has been an exodus of Nurse Coordinators in the last few years due to poor management, lack of support and a culture of fear.

job_title: Food Service Worker in Portland, OR
pros: As far as a job in food service, the pay is extremely competitive and you may not find that anywhere else in Portland. Benefits are incredible here, discounted trimet pass and if you work for food & nutrition, you get a discount at all the cafes/coffee shops. Most of my coworkers have been enjoyable to work with. If you have a job bid with regular days off, they will not schedule you to work those days ever, even when short staffed. AM shifts are eight hours long, so you can get 40 hours a week without ever being obligated to do a double and if you work nights, most of the shifts are less than seven hours but you do get paid a swing shift differential. Parking is free if you work weekends. While there is a lot of staffing issues in the patient services department, having the option to pull additional shifts can be nice at times when you want extra money.
cons: Large institution, bad work/life balance, no flexibility, long time to be promoted no matter how qualified you may be from past work experiences, and it can take a painfully long time to accomplish what you want. Management can make you feel very uncared for, especially if you haven’t worked there for a long time and have low seniority. Due to constantly being short staffed (unless you’ve worked there for years and have your regular position you do every day) your shifts are often getting switched/moved around, SOMETIMES changing the times you start and most of the time they “forget” to tell you in advance about it. Can’t always check your schedule because managers are making modifications to it 24/7. These days they are forcing a lot of newer employees to be trained on very intensive labor positions in the kitchen that not everyone wants to or CAN do, but they won’t make any of the high seniority employees do it at all because they were there “before the rules changed.” - Going with that, I see a lot of favoritism from the managers amongst specific employees and it seems like all they care about is getting coverage - it doesn’t seem like they even care about if people are happy or not there. Having paid vacation is nice, except you probably will get denied because you have to compete with senior employees for time off and due to the way that operations run, only two out of 20-30+ employees per division are allowed off on vacation at once, which is extremely frustrating and I personally feel like, should not be necessary.

pros:
With Michelle Sue as manager, she made sure all of our needs were taken care of. Proper equipment was always in the studios, she provided wonderful feedback to instructors, was open to having conversations with clients about which classes best suited their needs, assisted in accommodating instructors when they were in need of a sub etc. 

Overall, the pay for an instructor was decent in comparison to the going rate in Portland. They did offer paid time off, which was a wonderful benefit you almost never find in the fitness industry. Having access to the gym was a positive as well. 

Overall, they have many wonderful clients. People who attended my classes often became regular, friendly faces. I loved teaching here for that reason more than anything.
cons:
As soon as Michelle left and took on a new position, my experience with OHSU March Wellness went south. I'd worked for them for about 2 years at this point as a very loyal, dedicated employee. I would offer to take on 6 am shifts, sub for others when needed, and even offered to come in and teach when roads were icy and many other employees called in due to dangerous conditions. To say I was disappointed with the management change is an understatement. 

Instead of having support finding a sub when needed, it became our full responsibility if we couldn't find coverage. I realize this is the case with most studios, however I really appreciated Michelle's willingness to help when needed. People tend to respond more to management vs being asked by a co-worker. 

There came a time when I needed to shift my class to a different day/ time due to a schedule change. Fitness instructors schedules often need to shift slightly, as it is rarely our sole source of income. My intent was to keep the class and shift to a new day/time, or see if they would offer me any other class to teach. I have experience in many movement mediums, and feel they could've taken the time to utilize my skills. I hold a Bachelor of Arts degree in dance, a 200-hour yoga teacher training certification, can instruct basic pilates, have studied anatomy and physiology, etc. Especially having worked for them for 2 years, I didn't think this would be an issue. They proceeded to have me find a permanent replacement instructor for the class, and took me off of the schedule completely. They mentioned via Email that I should sub as I am able until a time slot opened up for me to teach again. Honestly I was a little frustrated that they showed no sign of appreciation for my teaching there, and instead were seeking out a way to get rid of me. From that point on, I received emails for 2 weeks about people needing subs. There were only two opportunities that arose, and I was unable to take them on due to scheduling conflicts. After those two weeks, I stooped receiving emails about subbing opportunities. By the end of the month, I'd received an email starting that I had "voluntarily quit' since I was unable to substitute a class that month. At this point, I was a bit offended after everything I've done for the company, and that I'd stopped receiving subbing opportunity emails after the two weeks. How could I take on opportunities if they were not given?  I may have been more forgiving had they taken the time to give me a phone call or an in-person conversation where they could explain their position. I sent an email to both the new manager and upper management about my frustrations with how the whole situation was handled. Nobody wrote me back to even confirm they'd received my message. 

The March Wellness and Fitness center has an enormous amount of work to do in standing by their mission to provide a holistic heath approach for all. They  can definitely work on being open to employee feedback, rather than dismissing it entirely.

review_title: It's going to be entirely dependent on who your boss is
job_title: Senior Research Assistant in Beaverton, OR
pros: I have an amazing boss out at the VGTI who makes work a complete joy. I've worked under someone else at OHSU in the past and it was a different experience. As long as you have a boss in your corner, working for OHSU itself is great.
cons: When you work on the hill on the main campus you can be exposed to some of the political stuff that goes on with the university. If you work out at west campus though you're shielded from the majority of it.

job_title: Cardiac Telemetry Tech in Portland, OR
pros: OHSU has been a great first step into the medical world. Bosting a great benefits package, great internal continuing education and a diverse campus.
cons: Unfortunately the pay rate in many positions is less the desirable. They no longer contribute to our 401k. We pay for parking 13 per day. No support from union.

review_title: OHSU would do well to prioritize research more effectively
job_title: Grants & Contracts Administrator in Portland, OR
pros: Excellent mission and colleagues. Good pay and benefits.
cons: Research is not prioritized as a value because "it does not bring in money". This causes serious underfunding for the Research Administration areas, which means that there are chronic staff shortages, which overtaxes employees and causes researchers projects to be delayed.

review_title: Medical Social Work within an institution
pros: OHSU is a teaching institution and there are tons of opportunities to learn and grow as a clinician, particularly if you work in the hospital. You can attend regular grand rounds and presentations. You will also work closely with resident physicians.
cons: There has been a ton of turn over in the SW department at OHSU in the past 3-4 years. Current management is pretty inflexible and demanding and can be very difficult to work with which makes for an unhappy working environment. OHSU as an institution does not value SW overly much either.

review_title: OHSU is the best biomedical research institution in Portland, OR
pros: By far the best thing about working at OHSU is the city of Portland. The people at OSHU are very conscientious about their work and generally very helpful and friendly.
cons: OHSU constantly struggles with financial concerns.  It's tough to tell if that's from its pathetic upper management of the University or its paltry endowment. Either way the school seems to be perennially struggling to cut corners.

pros: Good work life balance, with nearly 4 weeks of vacation time for all unclassified employees. TriMet annual pass is made available at a greatly reduced price.
cons: Parking at work is near impossible. Wait list for a spot is several years long so need to use public transit to get up and down the hill-adds time to the commute.

pros: Flexible schedule, generous benefits package (paid vacation and sick leave, affordable medical/dental/vision insurance, 12% retirement fund contribution)
cons: Low take-home pay, stressful work environment, leadership prone to top-down decision-making

review_title: OHSU is a great company to work for with hundreds of avenues for career change and growth.
job_title: Department Manager in Marquam Hill, OR
pros: Huge employer that does almost everything related to health care. A leader in the community and the state, people who are passionate about what they do and the role they play with the organization.
cons:
One Word: Bureaucracy
OHSU moves frustratingly slow due to the complexity of it's mission(s). Decisions are often made slowly and often they come from sources that are not available for discussion and have little contact with the day-to-day operations.

pros: Guaranteed pay raises because of the union. A teaching institution so you can learn a lot of skills to advance your career, not necessary within the organization however.
cons: Parking waitlist is 10 years long unless you're faculty. There is no diversity at the top or in non-support positions meaning that only 5% of minorities are earning more than $55K. The jobs are loaded so you're doing your bosses work and their bosses work but they're getting 6 figures. Jobs are misclassified.

pros: Some of the people that work there are nice
cons:
Toxic culture, managers expect the admins to do their jobs for them, raises are 1% a year no matter how hard you work. Managers are mean and power hungry. No one feels safe at their jobs. Culture is abusive. Unreasonable expectations placed on employees. Part of every admins job description is 10% projects as assigned so they can give you any projects even if they are out of your job description.
If you make a mistake it will always be brought back up and they never let you live it down. I am talking about mistakes like a typo in a email to a coworker.

pros: Great providers, especially nurse practitioners. Trans health programs is the best in the country. Community outreach, open 6 days/wk.
cons: Management is a mess, they pick favorites and use them to scope out new employees. Unapproachable, they don't handle conflict well and intentionally dismiss it. Medical Assistants are catty, rude, unprofessional and are incapable of training new employees with respect.  Turn over rate is HUGE. Do NOT work here if you want to be treated fairly. Run away as fast as you can. Other OHSU facilities do well, look at them. This clinic should not be associated with them, they do not reflect OHSU's mission.

review_title: OHSU is an okay place to work, but there are some problems.
pros: The work going on at OHSU is exciting and there are many features that are only available because OHSU is the main institution for the Oregon National research Primate center.  If you work at the ONRPC, there is plenty of free parking and the traffic is not that bad.
cons: The pay at OHSU is only given at the NIH standard for post-doctoral fellows. Also the medical insurance coverage is very restrictive with limited options and high costs.

pros: Great union, cost of living raise and 4% yearly raise so you get like a 25 cent raise every 6 mo. The company is very progressive in their stances- basically got a staff wide 'not my potus' email from the big wigs re Trump
cons: There is a 10 year long waitlist for employee parking. Many clinics have poor management and high turn over

pros: Had multiple jobs within this teaching university. Great culture of learning, and commitment to continuing education and diversity. As with any large employer, problems with administrative oversight, employee conflict, and workplace instability will inevitably surface from time to time. On the balance, however, I am happy to have been an employee at OHSU.
cons: Nothing that doesn't characterize any workplace setting from time to time - employee turnover, problems with administrative oversight, workplace conflict and instability.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Marquam Hill, OR
pros: Flexible hours, fun workforce, amazing location, subsidized Trimet pass, onsite farmer's market, supportive IT department, and a fairly free thinking culture of management.
cons: Low pay, no parking, transportation largely reliant on Trimet, run down facilities, no room for growth or career advancement, some management unfit for their rols (PhD does not qualify one to manage people).

review_title: Good Place for a Satisfying Career
job_title: Surgical Technologist in Marquam Hill, OR
pros: OHSU stays on top of the medical technology and advancements. They do a good job of keeping employees happy.
cons: Parking is a bummer here. 15$ a day to park at work? Its outrageous. Investigate alternate options for getting there.

pros: good benefits, client population, good coworkers
cons: Some management are entrenched and cannot expand beyond their narrow views, so at time felt the floor felt marginalized. The greatest con was the lateral violence that occurred for new nurses to start and work in the department. Older nurses were brutal. It was a horrible start and stayed that way for about 2 years.

review_title: Poor management leads to knee jerk reactions
job_title: Systems Analyst Engineer in Portland, OR
pros:
You could get away with doing almost no work.
If union, you'll get a pay raise regardless of quality of work.
cons: I got jerked around the whole time I was there, we kept starting projects and then scrapping them. In a year of work we managed to accomplish nothing. I left for a better company before they laid off my co-workers.

review_title: Fun, a lot of autonomy but bureaucratic to a fault
pros: Deep Tri-Met discount, autonomy while on the job, great views!
cons: unions = merit based work gets trumped by seniority. I love public transit, but if you want to drive and park your car at work, this isn't the place.

review_title: Great entry point in the medical fields
pros: OHSU provides an amazing opportunity to network within the medical field between a wide range of clinical and research professionals. If you're trying to get into any facet of the medical field, I strongly recommend pursuing positions at OHSU,
cons: Lengthy interview periods, poor HR coordination and transportation to work can be difficult. Be prepared to work in a very fast paced and challenging environment.

review_title: Great place to coast through your career
pros: The pay and benefits are great.  Work life balance is very good.  There is very little pressure to complete projects on time.
cons: Low risk tolerance discourages innovation and initiative.  Focus is on doing things the same way it's been done for years.  Very little collaboration between teams.

pros: Great place to work. Love the seminar, so you can educate yourself easily. Love the farmers market in the summer, get to eat so many delicious food and have a nice break around noon.
cons: Transportation is not very convienient. During winter time, without the farmers market, finding good food is hard. The library does not have a lot books, you need to borrow books from outside systems.

job_title: Respiratory Care Practitioner in Portland, OR
pros: The staff is awesome, the hospital itself is very nice. OHSU cares for some of the sickest patients in the state, it's great for gaining experience.
cons: Pays less then competitive hospitals, benefits are mediocre, ONLY SIX DAYS PTO A YEAR(until 5 years of service) Parking sucks, cafeteria is limited at night, Respiratory Therapist have a minor role compared to other hospitals. The RT department lacks in continuing education.

job_title: Certified Surgical Technologist in Portland, OR
pros: a lot of variety, good benefits
cons: OR management was absolutely terrible. I was written up multiple times for pregnancy related reason. I would not recommend working here if you plan on becoming pregnant. You will be discriminated against and constantly questioned about your choices especially if you are young and with child. I would never recommend working here even to my worst enemy, it was torture. I was constantly worried about loosing my job and my job was threated by 2 of the nurse managers on multiple occasions.

review_title: Be ready to deal with drug addicted co workers, It's a hospital after all
pros: Mostly nice people. Good benefits.
cons: Greedy executives. You need a Bachelors degree just to answer a phone. More than a few bad apples have spoiled the bunch. Ohsu will literally hire retarded people. This has its own set of pros and cons.

review_title: Healthcare organization that consistently pursues excellence and innovation.
job_title: PAS Resource Specialist in Portland, OR
pros: Supportive management, top notch professionals, compassionate care for both patients and employees, thorough training of new hires, friendly fellow employees.
cons: Since it is so large, there are times when certain protocol within each department is not very clear and defined.

review_title: Great place to work, yet limited ambition
pros: The pay and benefits were great, people were really nice. I loved my managers! It was an organized place to work.
cons: It is difficult to move up because it is based on seniority. The price for parking was awful, but fortunately they gave a small stipend for biking.

pros: Management was courteous, professional, and efficient. The work environment was welcoming. The pay was fair. Everything was clean. The food was tasty. Pretty view from the patio.
cons: Not very good cell service. Easy to get lost in the big hospital. Very limited parking. Lunch is not complementary. Wi-fi must be repeatedly logged onto throughout the day.

pros:
Portland area rocks. 
Some great people work here
cons:
Parking is pretty much non-existent
Managers are not accountable for how great or awful they are. Which leads to many awful managers. Many bullies.

review_title: Great Place to Learn and Grow
job_title: Medical Laboratory Technician in Marquam Hill, OR
pros: Great place to learn and grow. The OHSU core laboratory and satellite labs offer many testing opportunities for individuals who want to gain experience. Friendly, diverse atmosphere. Good benefits package right off the bat: medical, dental, vision, life, disability etc.
cons: Marquam Hill parking/commuting is absolutely horrendous, and something needs to be done. Cost of living is high, and MLT/MLS wages need to be better, especially if they want to attract talent and keep it.

pros:
Genuine respect for academic and clinical excellent
Support for staff in any position
Multiple Opportunities to grow, develop and advance
Diverse workgroup
Diverse patient populations
cons: Very large institution and is academic which makes the work very interesting but can be challenging until folks acclimate

review_title: Only growth is off the hill
job_title: Medical Laboratory Technician in Portland, OR
pros: Good work life balance, decent pay with wiggle room for experience.
cons: Politics on and off the hill are grossly different.

pros: OHSU offers great benefits and a has a healthy respect for work-life ratio. It makes working at OHSU a pleasant experience.
cons: The organization is risk averse and is slow to change.  Projects are rarely completed on schedule, or on budget.  The workplace leans extremely left politically, which can make for some uncomfortable hallway discussions.

review_title: Great place to start a career
job_title: Research Assistant I in Portland, OR
pros: Great people who are active in many areas of their life. Culture is great. People have a genuine interest to get to know each other.
cons: Pay is generally low and it is almost impossible to make a career change within the company. Note:former employee. Had to leave because I couldn't find a position within the company.

review_title: Thank Goodness for AFSCME at OHSU
pros: OHSU has benefits and many reasons to work here.
cons: Thank Goodness for AFSCME at OHSU however since the Union has to protect employees' wages and benefits. Without a Union, OHSU would pay below scale and still demand excellence in all areas of Customer Service for a low, bargain-basement price

pros:
team work, academic environment and fast paced - really smart people.

Very team oriented environment, and people are always willing to help out one another.
cons: stress, hours, schedule, but this goes with the territory of being in the medical field, esp, in the position choosen

review_title: Awesome experience of being a Laboratory Assistant
pros: Great PIs, access to government funded research materials, primate center, great networking opportunities, knowledge that you are contributing to actual medicine (not big pharma)
cons: Not as much pay as capitalist research, employment more dependent on grants/funds, sometimes certain PIs could be very grating; otherwise, it's really difficult to say anything negative. Favorite job I've had.

review_title: not very exciting, just so so
pros: not very busy, you have balanced work and life here in my job position.
cons: salary under median level (close to the low bound ) based on journal survey. every year need to worry about next year's funding. no promotion for this position. no enough career network in this position.

pros:
Very good work culture: family values first, job duties second. Very refreshing and positive outlook. 
4 weeks of paid vacation with a max of 6.5 weeks. having to take vacation because you have too much is a good problem to have.
cons: Parking is scarce and expensive. Salaries are a bit lower than average for the area, but they make up for it in benefits, work flexibility and perks.

job_title: IT Field Technology Analyst in Houston, TX
pros: Great pay and benefits.  Wonderful place to work and worth the effort to get in.  Worked Monday through Friday exclusively and had option for overtime if wanted.
cons: None, I can't think of anything that I didn't like about working at Oregon Health and Science University.

job_title: Room Service Associate in Portland, OR
pros: Employee benefits, great healthcare package, personal/career development courses available, subsidized public transport pass, education reimbursement options. Great cohesion with coworkers.
cons: Food and Nutrition doesn't have a lot of flexibility with scheduling for PM workers (2:30-10PM 5 days/ week), however if your personal life aligns with this, it's not a big deal, I made friends with people who had similar schedules and I ended up saving more money with this schedule.

review_title: The only biomedical emphasis university in Portland and Oregon in general.
job_title: Senior, Research Associate in Portland, OR
pros: The overall atmosphere of the research side of OHSU is casual and laid back, even amongst high profile scientists.
cons: There are VERY limited growth opportunities if you join as a postdoc.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Portland, OR
pros: Working at OHSU is great overall.  It's a cutting edge public hospital with many avenues to progress if that is your intention.  Being in float pool I worked all over the hospital and some of teams were wonderful, others were not.
cons:
Public hospital means the hardest cases.
Support medical staff like CNAs don't get the perks everyone else does.
Parking is awful.

review_title: Very positive experience, great boss and benefits, low pay.
pros: If you are working full-time, you will have access to some great medical and other benefits, time off, etc.
cons: As an employee in a research position that required a Bachelor's, I felt I should have been making more per hour than I did at Home Depot...

pros: A good company that provides steady employment with higher than average salaries.
cons: A lot of politics and bureaucracy which makes change difficult.  There is not a lot of professional growth within the academic institutions.

pros: Our department is full of wonderful, fun, intelligent people. The work hours are very flexible. If your PI is anything like mine, you will be given creative and intellectual space. Benefits (medical, dental, vision)  are also almost fully covered.
cons: Pay is pretty low for the workload, true with any research job. There is some expectation for working nights and weekends, again depending on the PI and project.

pros: Great benefits; great pay; beautiful campus
cons: The 1 year contracted management supervising represented employees does not work!  Personally, I think it makes insecure managers mean which makes for an unpleasant working environment.

pros: Decent benefits, nice people, ok salary
cons:
Almost impossible to advance in current position even though you continue to add responsibilities and work, and your pay is only bumped up per union contract. Experience, hard work, internal knowledge don't mean anything.

Also, overall benefits are good, but for a hospital, medical benefits are pretty expensive and pretty average coverage.

job_title: Senior Research Associate in Portland, OR
pros: The work environment is very nice and everyone is very helpful.
cons: Since our research is grant based we have to always think about how we will be able to have a flow of money for continuing our research even after working for seventeen years in the same department.

pros: I met 8 members of the department and they were friendly and asked open questions. They encouraged team work.
cons: The possible PI told that he was going to set a date for me to give a talk to his group and meet with him after a 2 days of series of interviews, but he never got back to me. Tried to email him a couple of time but he did not return/respond to my emails.

review_title: Amazing place to learn and grow
pros: Very complex work environment, which makes learning more interesting than at a smaller healthcare organization; wonderful people; very smart senior leaders; positive work environment
cons: A lot of information does not trickle down to lower level employees or front line staff--senior leaders need to be more transparent and visible; parking is expensive, IF you can get a spot on the hill at all!

review_title: Great experience, an excellent place to study if you choose the right advisor
Busy tertiary center with well rounded resident training.
pros: Large hospital with pediatric and va buildings.  Excellent access to wide breadth of cases and patients.  Support staff were very nice and helpful.  Good teamwork and collaboration.
cons: Hours were long and became longer with hospital admin trying to optimize cost, which was stressful to faculty and residents.  It was a sprawling facility with a significant amount of walking.

review_title: Beautiful place to work. Smart people. Hard to get ahead. Low pay.
pros: If you like the NW, working at OHSU is heaven. On top of a hill overlooking scenic Portland, you can't beat it! People care about their work here and love meeting new faces.
cons: It's very difficult to get a job here none the less move up the latter. The pay for lower-mid level positions is not competitive.

review_title: good benefit, lousy salary for RA
pros: it really depends on who you work for, if you get a reasonable boss, your life will be a breeze, pretty standard 9-5pm jobs, great health benefit as well as retirement plan
cons: if you got a bad boss, then your life is hell, i'd suggest find another one, there's plenty of opportunities for internal transfer

review_title: Overall a very welcoming and good work environment.
pros: Amazing benefits, beautiful campus, the feeling of helping people, and the opportunities to grow are endless.
cons: Unorganized at times and lack of discipline on those who let patient care slip away.

review_title: Working with beautiful view and weather and less stress
pros:
I am working here as a full time graduate student. I think the most good thing here is environment.
The city is generally safe, weather is mild and people is generous. As a graduate student I can enjoy my academic study balancing with family affair with less stress.
cons: As a student, insurance is really poor in contrast to normal employee.

review_title: Research jobs are underpaid, like they are everywhere
job_title: Senior Research Assistant in Portland, OR
pros: Great benefits and paid time off
cons: In research, there is no upward mobility for someone without an advanced degree

review_title: OHSU is a pretty good place to work
pros: Great benefits, multiple locations with new opportunities that can come at any time
cons: As a large healthcare organization, OHSU isn't managed better or worse than other large healthcare organizations which rarely at the top of the class in terms of how well they are managed.  Sometimes they overspend then have a knee jerk reaction when they start getting financially tight.

job_title: Data Analyst in Lake Oswego, OR
pros: Benefits, insurance, flexible time. This is typical State job.
cons: Just because university is in the name, does not mean they are forward thinking. Think about healthcare professionals trying to do Data Warehouse work and then IT getting their way by using fear of failure.

pros: Work with investigators at the forefront of biomedical research.  Working with non-human primates is interesting.
cons: Very low upward mobility, if they get you to work in a job that nobody wants, they won't let you move on. Political hiring and favoritism.

review_title: Good environment but often difficult collaboratively
pros:
Good benefits
Freedom to collaborate across departments
Positive graduate student culture
cons:
Lack of clarity in departmental goals and responsibilities
Lack of intermediate faculty positions overtaxes senior faculty
Some very negative stories regarding student experience

review_title: Small Academic Medical Center with Big Dreams
pros:
wage/salary
academics and research
striving to improve
cons:
Disorganized physician structures and leadership
Focuses too much on the vision and dreams instead of the current reality

pros: You get to work on interesting projects with some of the latest research/tools.
cons: If your position is grant funded, you can expect a lot of volatility here. I've had four different positions at OHSU, and three of them ended with layoffs due to grant funding issues.

pros:
> Great benefits, including healthcare, dental, vision, etc. 
> Public transit discounts
> Employee Assistance Program
> Generally stable working environment
cons:
> Bloated hierarchy
> Not at all nimble when it comes to addressing needs/concerns/new projects
> Female administrative support staff frequently overlooked for promotion

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Portland, OR
pros: WFH (work-from-home) options in some depts, union benefits including 2 promised raises per year to include cost of living, many locations
cons: Not too many to report at this time, I really love my dept; the work can be overwhelming at times but this is similar to many jobs (volume, pace, etc). Can be very difficult to get into OHSU.

review_title: run like a factory, not a university
pros: Great students, intelligent,motivated.  Good infrastructure, support services
cons: Horrible human resources, very poor medical benefits for a health focused company. Lack of coherent policies and procedures, many faculty are on annual contracts which are often not renewed.

pros: Good pay, paid ZERO dollars/month for health insurance premium, a couple of fabulous coworkers, learned a ton
cons: WORKED EIGHT-HOUR NIGHT SHIFTS!!, parking is terrible for day shift, location of hospital is annoying, management was terrible, unit educator was terrible, some very mean coworkers

pros: OHSU is proactively trying to drive an inclusive and patient-centered mission forward. Good place to work, there is an expansion of the research branch, the location is great with beautiful views of the river and the city. Good benefits.
cons: RA salary not great, slightly lower than other institutions I've worked at, but can vary with the specific position

review_title: Union Environment, full bens, medical enviroment
job_title: Patient Access Representative in Beaverton, OR
pros: Good bens, classes for career and personal growth, trimet discount
cons: career path gets blocked, cross training not fostered, management secretive/not transparent. Sudden changes made without advice of staff. Understaffed usually, disgruntled and overworked employees. As a new employee you don't get manager support to ensure a comfortable transition to the department.

review_title: good views from a high acuity hospital
pros:
pay is good
views are amazing from most patient rooms
union protection
decent autonomy in practice
teaching environment gives staff nurses purpose
cons:
very bureaucratic 
organizational executives having a hard time dealing with changing health care industry 
executives make ill informed changes that create barriers to growth

review_title: Good Overall but Unequal Job Classification
pros: I received positive feedback from superiors (quite high up within OHSU because of my position) and felt respected.
cons: My position was demoted shortly after my departure despite clearly being of a higher level than most executive assistants simply because of who I worked for.

pros: The benefits are great (I'm a union represented employee), lots of resources, tons of advancement opportunities once you are an internal candidate for openings.
cons: The company's overall attitude of "do more with less"; paid, limited parking, so my 25 minute drive to work has become a 1.5 hour each way bus commute.

job_title: Associate Project Manager in Portland, OR
pros: Benefits, Design & Construction Team, Great Culture, Diversity
cons: Micro management, lack of interdepartmental working relationships - departments seem to be out for themselves and not willing to work with other departments

pros: Decent benefits, pay and ability to move up if you want to.
cons: Sketchy management, lots of hoops and policies that are very old school thinking not as progressive as it leads on to be. Don’t care about employee satisfaction

pros:
Beautiful location and facilities.
Excellent CORE facilities.
cons:
No mid-career guidance or direction.
Little to no $ commitment from OHSU after startup despite HUGE $ donations.
Focus is on the few major scientists
Dept micromanaging

job_title: Research Assistant II in Portland, OR
pros: If you have a good PI or Post-Doc, you will likely find yourself with more independence and responsibility in the lab.
cons: Retirement provider could be better, and orientation is heavily focused at the medical mission.

job_title: Business Data Analyst in Portland, OR
pros: Great Benefits. Culture within each department can vary widely. Some departments create an open, transparent, and cohesive workgroup.
cons: Some departmental leadership can be be very difficult to work for. Look at recent turnover rate for a hint to departmental culture.

pros: Outstanding benefits, flexibility with work schedule and telecommuting.
cons: Very toxic work environment in the Knight Cancer Research department where there was a lot of favoritism of employees regardless of work performance.  The turnover rate is very high and many have left to go to competitor at Providence and have shared their terrible experience at the Knight.

pros: Accomplished and respected faculty in many biomedical fields. Reputation brings in   world class scientists for local talks and seminars. Excellent resources and support staff.
cons: OHSU administration favors clinical/medical research over more basic sciences. No undergrads and a small number of grad students, meaning few opportunities to gain teaching experience.

pros: It is a large corporation so the financial benefits are good. The vacation and leave benefits are generous. Salaries are more or less competitive.
cons: The work culture is stuck in the 80s or 90s.  People can be fairly stuck up.

review_title: It's an okay place to work.
job_title: Research Assistant II in Portland, OR
pros: Various employee discounts through vendors and other big companies  in Portland like Nike and Addidas
cons: The salary is not good at all. It under pays.

pros: Celebrate diversity, innovative, great compensation for a university, welcoming environment.
cons: Some roles can leave you rather stuck in terms of growth, but if you connect with the right people, they may be able to help you determine new roles.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Aurora, CO
pros: It was amazing working with the patients.  Most of the former co-workers were wonderful as well.
cons: KCVI is an environment where staff are allowed to backdate and participate in other activities that questions study integrity.   Staff favoritism and bullying are also prominent here.  Since all research staff are unclassified, there is no recourse if one behaves inappropriately towards you. There is no union to protect you.

pros: Portland is an amazing city and OHSU is an exciting institution and great work environment.
cons: Weather in Portland is an obvious downside. Parking is a major issue. The usual hospital administration woes, but no worse than other hospitals I've worked at.

review_title: Glad to have a job at OHSU
pros: OHSU is on the cutting edge of so many miraculous medical miracles.
cons: Executive leadership can  often pick a project/issue of the quarter but then not keep  it up, just letting it drop after others have invested much time and effort.

review_title: Mostly positive, wish that employees with poor performance would be let go after so many chances of failing to improve.
pros: I get to do what I love, get paid pretty well, schedule is pretty good, but not ideal.
cons: Benefits are getting cut each year.

job_title: Public Service Representative in Portland, OR
pros: Loved the values, benefits, and environment.  Lots of opportunity to excel and learn new skills.  Especially appreciated the discounted Tri-Met pass.
cons: Can't think of any right now.

job_title: Behavioral Health Consultant in Scappoose, OR
pros: One of the funnest, most rewarding experiences I have ever had. The atmosphere of the setting and heavy reliance on Behavioral Health staff demonstrates the agency's and the medical providers value of helping the clientele
cons: Lots of patriarchal beliefs among medical providers - pretty sure this is standard in medical settings.

pros: Great employees and they really know why they are there for. Very helpful and always offering to help each other out.
cons: I don’t support all the LGBT, and it seems that OHSU supports it and takes pride in it. Other than this, all is beyond great. Heath benefits are okay.

job_title: Managed Care Coordinator in Portland, OR

Great Employees

3 minuet grace time in the morning.

pros: Diversity, culture, patient safety and being on the leading edge of medicine!
cons: Getting to work is like an adventure. I say this because you can’t really park and the traffic is heavy the closer in you get so you must be ready to do what it takes just to get to work.

pros:
-Wonderful, hard working and kind people whom you get to know on an individual basis

job_title: Research Assistant II in Portland, OR
pros: You are paid a small monthly stipend (~$20/month) extra to bike to work. Nice views from some of the research labs.
cons: Poorly run research departments. Large administrative bureaucracy (as with many teaching hospitals these days). Marquam Hill campus is isolated with poor food options and expensive parking.

pros: The people at OHSU genuinely want to do the right thing, especially for patients.
cons: Lack of strategic leadership and conflict at the highest levels leads to regular turnover, restructuring, and financial uncertainty.

review_title: A stimulating and exciting place to work
pros: The university is growing, lots of intellectual resources and cross pollination, support for nursing mothers, relative independence between departments
cons: HR is difficult to navigate, parking is very expensive, campus is somewhat isolated and it takes a long time to travel from one end to the other.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Portland, OR
pros: Small program so tuned to your specific needs. Most PI's are friendly and easy to get along with and collaborate with. Not having undergraduates means no TA work required.
cons: It is a small program so maybe not as many resources available to you as would be at a larger university.

pros: Amazing benefits, pay, work environment and culture. I loved the team I worked for and overall, had great experiences with all the employees I met.
cons: No employee parking on campus. You to pay $$$ for a spot but you wouldn’t wont get one because the waiting list is never ending longgg

job_title: Health Unit Coordinator in Portland, OR
pros: This company is a great company to work for.  The benefits are solid, the pay is competitive, the environment and staff are passionate and competent.  I loved it here!
cons: Not much in the way of cons.  Work hard and you will be rewarded.

job_title: Patient Access Specialist in Portland, OR
pros:
-Good work environment, inclusive
-Good benefits and pay
-Most people seem to genuinely care about doing a good job
cons:
-Lack of management communication to employees
-Job description does not match actual duties

review_title: Wonderful environment for high quality clinical education
pros: Camaraderie is excellent among the faculty, fellows and residents. The faculty at OHSU is exceedingly supportive and people are happy working here. It is a great research institute, offering excellent clinical education in a collegial atmosphere.
cons: Convincing my family to move to Portland

pros: You get a paycheck. Overtime is usually available. Good company to work for. Opportunities to move up are available as well.
cons: Parking is a major problem if you work in the hill. Wages have not caught up with the cost of living in Portland.

review_title: OHSU produces high quality research in a collaborative environment.
pros: Collaborative biomedical research towards making advances in treatment outcomes. They offer great medical and retirement benefits. Great opportunities for career development
cons: Location is hard to get to and there is no affordable parking for employees. Commute is long for many people.

pros: Benefits, wages, union representation; learning environment; opportunity to interface with great variety of people.
cons: Old school system. Need to learn and play by the rules. Huge organization. Must routinely check that your paycheck is accurate (often hours missing).

review_title: Great place for me at the time.
pros: I worked part time and still had benefits.  Everyone in my small group were very supportive, friendly, and helpful.  Hours were flexible.
cons: Lack of parking meant having to commute to work every day.  Other than that, everything was quite positive.

pros: Financially stable, outstanding benefits, avante garde environment, great pay
cons: So large that there are many hoops to jump through to get things done (too many hands in the pot)

pros: great benifits, vacation, sick days. depending on your unit, you can be well supported at work.

review_title: I was a postdoc in genetics--it was great.

pros: Amazing work group, great benefits, great retirement options.

pros: The university is doing cutting edge research in the field of neuroscience, molecular biology, and cancer therapies.

pros: Great patients, some of the coworkers are wonderful, some exciting medical research

pros: 24 hours open cafeteria, up to date technology.

pros: Good benefits,   Be careful which department you work for.  Some are great, others have poor managers.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Portland, OR

review_title: Okay place to work if you are not ambitious
